The late 1990s saw a surge in violence and intimidation faced by abortion clinics in the United States and Canada. According to a survey, more than half of the clinics reported some form of intimidation, with one-quarter experiencing it on a daily basis. This intimidation can take many forms, including stalking, facility invasions, and blockades, which put the lives of physicians, nurses, and clinic staffers at risk. The clinics were subjected to various types of opposition, including protests and blockades, which prevented women from getting the care they need. In some cases, the opposition escalated to targeting the homes and churches of healthcare providers, as seen in the case of Kansas physician George Tiller. However, the response of law enforcement has been criticized for being inadequate, particularly in cases where clinics have been subjected to repeated threats and intimidation. The impact of the violence on the clinics and the women they serve has been devastating, with nearly 20 percent of clinics having been subject to threats or violence in the past year.

The violence and intimidation faced by abortion clinics in the late 1990s had a significant impact on the women they serve. Women were often too frightened to enter the clinic to get the care they need, due to the threats and intimidation they faced. The impact of the law on abortion access was significant, with several other states enacting similar 20-week bans.

The law will have the most devastating impact on abortion access of any such restriction across the country, with one out of six Texan women seeking an abortion now living more than 150 miles from the nearest clinic. Unless the Supreme Court steps in, the law is poised to have a significant impact on abortion access, particularly for women living in rural areas.

topic: Write a report that describes the 1998 federal budget negotiations, the issues that delayed the negotiations, and the eventual agreement that was reached.

report: Budget negotiations between the White House and House Republicans were delayed on several issues. At issue were provisions that included requiring Federal Health Insurance providers to provide contraceptives to women as Well as a provision to build a road across a wildlife preserve in Alaska. The contraceptive issue faced an uncertain future while Clinton likely will veto the road. There is disagreement also on how to spend the funding on education. This year's budget discussions also have been hampered because it is the first time since budget procedures were established in 1974 that there has been a surplus, preventing agreement on a budget resolution. Whether to use the 1st surplus in decades for a tax cut, to pay off the national debt, or for new initiatives made the 1998 federal budget negotiations chaotic. The Oct 1 start of the fiscal year was extended 5 times. Major issues were census statistical sampling, federal health plan coverage of contraceptives regardless of religious affiliation, and school aid decisions by the federal gov't or local jurisdictions. Other issues included a Federal Election Commission provision, a road through an Alaskan wildlife refuge, and an airline peanut ban. Committees crafted the budget document after broad agreement was reached when 8 bills were lumped together. In 1998, for the first time in decades, the US budget negotiators faced a surplus. Both sides said this was harder than a deficit situation, but they finally spent $1.7 trillion. The last seven spending bills were the most difficult and finally were merged into one package. Controversial issues included health insurance paying for contraception, control of new education allocations, an Alaskan wilderness road, whether the 2000 census would include statistical sampling, and establishing an emergency fund. Conservatives felt the results favored the liberals, but both sides were satisfied and glad to finish before Election Day and avoid a government shutdown. After several deadline extensions, Congressional leaders and the White House agreed on an omnibus spending package, the final portion of the $1.7 trillion budget. It includes more money for education and defense, business tax breaks, and farm aid, as well as funds for Colombia to use in drug interdiction. To offset the new spending, the surplus will be tapped for $20 billion, to the ire of conservatives. This year, without the common goal of reducing the deficit, reaching agreement was very difficult. Policy provisions involving the 2000 census, contraception, and the Alaskan wilderness were also tied to the spending package and were hotly debated.
response:

The talks between President Bill Clinton, Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott, and House Speaker Newt Gingrich were ongoing for several weeks, with both sides trying to reach an agreement on several outstanding issues. One of the major issues that delayed the negotiations was the estate tax, which was a contentious point between Democrats and Republicans. The Democrats wanted to raise the estate tax exemption, while the Republicans were opposed to any increase in the tax. Another issue that caused delays was the sequester, which was a provision that would automatically cut spending if an agreement was not reached. The sequester was seen as a draconian measure by many lawmakers, and both sides were hesitant to implement it. Despite the challenges, the negotiators were able to reach a compromise that raised the estate tax exemption and avoided the sequester. The agreement, which was reached in August 1998, was seen as a good first step by President Clinton, who praised the deal as a "modest but necessary step forward". The agreement set spending levels for the federal government for two years and partially replaced unpopular spending cuts with other savings. While the agreement was not perfect, it was seen as a significant accomplishment in the ongoing budget negotiations, and it paved the way for future agreements. The negotiations were a testament to the ability of lawmakers to work together and find common ground, even in the face of significant disagreement. Overall, the 1998 federal budget negotiations were a complex and challenging process, but ultimately resulted in a modest agreement that avoided significant tax hikes and spending cuts.

topic: Provide a report on the launch and initial assembly of the International Space Station. Include information on the modules involved, the spacecraft used, the launch dates, the assembly process, and the estimated time and resources needed to complete the space station.
questions: What was the initial plan for the launch of the Zarya module?

report: After discarding a suggested change of orbit, the Russian Space Agency went ahead with plans to launch its Zarya module of the international space station on Nov. 20, 1998. Although delayed for a day, U.S. plans to launch the space shuttle Endeavour carrying the U.S. module Unity and six astronauts were carried out on Dec. 4. The astronauts' job was to connect Unity with the already-orbiting Zarya as the first step in assembling 100 major components of the planned space station. Using the shuttle's 50-foot robot arm, the two modules were joined setting the stage for a spacewalk by two astronauts the next day to attach electrical connectors and cables. The International Space Station when completed will have a million pound mass and be longer than a football field. It will house up to seven space explorers. The initial assembly of space station components involves linking the US Unity, carried into space by the shuttle Endeavour, with the Russian Zarya. The Russians had asked for a different launch profile in order to be able to transfer equipment from its MIR station, but that was not possible. Endeavour astronauts successfully completed the complicated maneuvers to join the two space objects. NASA estimates that 43 more launches will be required to completely assemble the 16-nation space station. On Friday the shuttle Endeavor carried six astronauts into orbit to start building an international space station. The launch occurred after Russia and U.S. officials agreed not to delay the flight in order to orbit closer to MIR, and after a last-minute alarm forced a postponement. On Sunday astronauts joining the Russian-made Zarya control module cylinder with the American-made module to form a 70,000 pounds mass 77 feet long. NASA estimates 43 more launches and 159 more space walks are needed to assemble the complex. When completed the 16-nation space station will be longer than a football field. It will be used to study adaptation to space flight. Russia and NASA jointly decided against a Russian cost-cutting proposal to orbit the 2nd space station, a 16-country cooperative project, closer to Mir, citing complexity, risk, and bad sun angles. After 5 years of assembly, the research station will house 7 people. A 12-day shuttle mission will attach the US Unity module to the Russian Zarya, already in orbit. Thursday's launch was delayed by a pressure drop. A 2nd attempt Friday was perfect. Unity was attached to Zarya in a blind docking using cameras and computer images. Electrical and cable connections come next. Unity will serve as a passageway for future modules. Two Zarya antennas failed to deploy.
response:
The International Space Station (ISS) was a monumental undertaking that required the collaboration of multiple nations and the assembly of numerous modules. The process began with the launch of the first piece, Zarya, on a Russian Proton booster rocket from the Baikonur cosmodrome in Kazakhstan. Zarya, a crucial component of the station, was built in Russia with $240 million from the United States and was designed to provide electricity and steering for the fledgling space station until a permanent control module could be launched next summer. The module was followed by the launch of the Unity module, a docking hub carried by the space shuttle Endeavour, which successfully docked with Zarya two weeks later. This marked a significant milestone in the assembly of the ISS, demonstrating the capabilities of the shuttle's robot arm and the precision of the astronauts.

The joined modules, consisting of Zarya and Unity, were released from Endeavour once all the work was completed, marking the beginning of a long process that would require 43 more launches and 159 more spacewalks to assemble the entire orbiting complex. The ISS would eventually grow into the largest orbital laboratory in history, housing up to seven astronauts and cosmonauts and having a mass of 1 million pounds, making it longer than a football field. The assembly process was complex and involved multiple nations, with the space shuttle Endeavour playing a crucial role in transporting and assembling the various modules. The shuttle's 12-day flight included three spacewalks to install handrails and other tools for future crews, marking an important step towards the completion of the ISS.

The successful docking of Zarya and Unity demonstrated the precision and capabilities of the astronauts and the shuttle's robot arm, paving the way for future construction and assembly of the ISS. report: 1,000 people mourned Matthew Shepherd, the gay University of Wyoming student who was severely beaten and left to die tied to a fence. The crime sparked nationwide vigils and prompted President Clinton to call for federal hate-crimes legislation. In 19 states, including Colorado, sexual orientation is not included in hate-crime laws. Wyoming is one of 10 states with no hate-crime laws at all, but the governor appealed to lawmakers to reconsider their opposition. Christian conservatives argue that hate-crime laws restrict freedom of speech, while gay rights activists and others say these laws send a message that attacks on minorities will not be tolerated. A passerby who found Matthew Shepard's nearly lifeless body tied to a fence outside Laramie, Wyoming at first thought it was a scarecrow. Matthew, an openly gay student at the University of Wyoming, had been kidnapped, brutally beaten and left to die in near freezing temperatures. Two men, Russell Henderson and Aaron McKinney were arrested on charges of kidnapping and attempted first degree murder. Two women, friends of the accused, were charged as accessories after the fact. Seeing this as a hate crime, gay-rights activists nationwide renewed efforts to get the Clinton Administration to pass hate-crime legislation. A 22-year old gay University of Wyoming student was found beaten and left to die lashed to a fence. Two men were arraigned on kidnapping, robbery, and attempted murder charges (changed to murder after Shepard died) and two females were charged as accessories. Expressions of sympathy came from across the nation, including President Clinton and the crime was widely denounced. The savage nature of the crime renewed calls for enactment of hate-crimes legislation. The House passed a resolution calling the killing "outrageous". On the day Shepard died, the Family Research Council co-hosted a press conference to demonize gay people. Two men in Wyoming kidnapped, robbed, and brutally beat a gay university student who died in a coma five days after the assault. The incident fanned public outrage. Hundreds in Laramie and on campuses across the nation demonstrated support to the student with marches and candlelight vigils. President Clinton responded to nationwide calls by urging Congress to pass the Federal Hate Crimes Protection Act. Gay leaders stressed that hostility towards gays, based on several surveys, flourishes in high schools and universities. By coincidence, on the day of the beating a religious right organization in Washington was announcing a barrage of TV ads aimed at gays.
response:
The brutal beating and murder of Matthew Shepard, a 21-year-old gay college student, in October 1998, sent shockwaves across the nation, sparking widespread outrage, vigils, and debates over hate-crimes legislation. According to Brian Levin, director of the Center for the Study of Hate and Extremism, the attack was seen as a hate crime, with many believing that Shepard was targeted because of his sexual orientation. The incident occurred on October 7, 1998, when Shepard was abducted and driven to a remote area east of Laramie, Wyoming, where he was tied to a fence, beaten with the butt of a pistol, and left to die. Almost 18 hours later, he was found by a bicyclist who initially mistook him for a scarecrow, and Shepard died five days later at Poudre Valley Hospital in Fort Collins, Colorado.

The attack on Shepard sparked a wave of protests and activism that led to the passage of the Matthew Shepard and James Byrd Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act, which expanded federal hate crime laws to include attacks motivated by a victim’s gender or sexual orientation. President Clinton called for federal hate-crimes legislation in response to the incident, highlighting the need for stronger laws to protect marginalized communities. The incident also fueled debates over hate-crimes legislation in Western states, including Wyoming, which has resisted such laws.

Matthew Shepard became a symbol of anti-gay violence and a catalyst for change, with people gathering from Denver to the University of Maryland to honor him and demand justice. The University of Wyoming, where Shepard was a student, also took steps to address the incident, with some students calling for greater support for the LGBTQ community. However, the incident also highlighted the need for continued activism and advocacy to address the ongoing challenges faced by the LGBTQ community, including hate crimes and discrimination.

In the aftermath of the attack, Russell Henderson and Aaron McKinney were arraigned on charges of kidnapping, aggravated robbery, and attempted first-degree murder, while two women, Kristen Leann Price and Chastity Vera Pasley, were charged as accessories after the fact to attempted first-degree murder. The incident served as a wake-up call for many, highlighting the need for greater awareness and understanding of the challenges faced by the LGBTQ community and the importance of advocating for stronger hate crime laws to protect marginalized communities. As Brian Levin noted, "Because of their social stature in society, gays are often viewed as appropriate targets". The legacy of Matthew Shepard continues to inspire activism and advocacy for LGBTQ rights, with many working to ensure that his memory is not forgotten and that his death was not in vain. As two decades have passed since the tragic event, some progress has been made toward LGBTQ equality, but obstacles still remain, and advocates continue to push for greater progress and understanding. report: NASA and the Russian Space Agency readied the first part of an international space station for launch from Baikonur base. They decided not to change the orbit of the Zarya module as Russia had requested. Zarya's Nov. 20 launch was a success. The Zarya module orbited Earth for 2 weeks before a rendezvous with U.S. shuttle Endeavor to join it to the Unity module. It was tweaked and working well. It will serve as a space tugboat. The first 2 building blocks of the international space station were successfully joined by Endeavor astronauts in the shuttle's open cargo bay. Endeavor astronauts made 2 of 3 planned spacewalks to work on the space station modules. Russia launched the first piece of the international space station into orbit a year after the originally scheduled date. The launch follows a last minute Russian request to change the orbit of the space station to put it closer to Mir. This request was set aside. Two weeks later, the U.S. carried the Unity chamber into orbit. U.S. astronauts aboard the Endeavor shuttle then joined the Unity chamber to the Russian Zarya control module. The resulting 7 story structure appeared to be a perfect fit. In a subsequent second space walk, the astronauts were to install antennas on the Unity chamber as well as to attempt to unjam a Russian antenna. After a year's delay Russia launched the first unit of the international space station, then pushed it to a higher orbit. Zarya will provide propulsion, power, and comms. US shuttle Endeavour made a blind docking with Zarya. Two spacewalks made electrical connections with Unity, which will serve as a passageway, attached its antennas and attempted to open a stuck Zarya antenna. A Russian cost-cutting proposal to orbit the station closer to Mir jointly vetoed. Russia promised to destroy Mir but now wants to extend its life. Russia sold early research time on the station to NASA to pay construction costs but claims the management lead for 1st 5 years. Jerry Ross and James Newman spacewalked to attach antennas to Unity, the American half of the first stage of the 16-nation space station. Unity will be a connecting passageway for other modules. The other portion of the fledgling station, the Russian- built and launched Zarya module, will provide power and propulsion to the facility. The successful launch of Zarya, which had been delayed over a year due to funding woes, was hailed by the Russian Space Agency head as proof that the Russian space industry "is perfectly able to fulfill all of its commitments on the international space station". Russia is scheduled to launch the crew module next year.
response:
The first part of the international space station, which marked a major milestone in its construction, began with the successful launch of the Zarya module on a Russian Proton booster rocket from the Baikonur cosmodrome in Kazakhstan. The 1998 Nobel for medicine was awarded to three US researchers for discoveries with nitric oxide. 1998's Nobel prize for literature went to a Portuguese for the 1st time, imaginative novelist Jose Saramago, long a candidate. Portugal celebrated but the Vatican called him a communist and anti-religious. The meaning of Nobel's advice to honor "literature that works in an ideal direction" is unclear. 3 Americans won in medicine for 1980s discoveries concerning nitric oxide's function in the body, which sparked new research. Nobel nominations are secret. Prizes are awarded on Dec. 10th, the day of Nobel's death, all in Stockholm except the Peace prize in Oslo. The 1978 committee wanted to give the Peace Prize to Jimmy Carter but missed its own deadline. Jose Saramago is the first Portuguese-language writer and one of few communists to win the Nobel Prize for Literature. He is widely acclaimed for his imaginative allegories. Three American researchers, Robert Furchgott, Louis Ignarro, and Ferid Murad, shared the 1998 Nobel Prize for Medicine for discovering how nitric oxide acts as a signal molecule in the cardiovascular system. response:
The Nobel Prize is one of the most prestigious awards globally, recognizing outstanding contributions in various fields, including literature, peace, and medicine. Since its inception, the Nobel Prize has been awarded to individuals who have made significant contributions to the betterment of humanity. The selection process for the Nobel Peace Prize involves a thorough evaluation of nominations submitted by qualified individuals, who must meet specific categories. The Norwegian Nobel Committee, composed of five members appointed by the Storting (Norwegian parliament), assesses the candidates based on their contributions to peace and conflict resolution. Yehoshua, and Doris Kareva, who may not be as well-known internationally but could still potentially win the award. In recent years, the Nobel Prize in Medicine has recognized groundbreaking research in the fields of immunology and cancer treatment. The 2013 Nobel Prize in Medicine was awarded to James Rothman, Randy Schekman, and Thomas Südhof for their discoveries of the molecular machinery governing membrane traffic. This breakthrough has led to a better understanding of how cells communicate with each other, and has paved the way for new treatments for various diseases. The 2022 Nobel Prize in Medicine was awarded to Svante Pääbo for his discoveries concerning the genomes of extinct hominins and human evolution. These discoveries have significantly advanced our understanding of human evolution and the origins of our species.

In conclusion, the Nobel Prize is a prestigious award that recognizes outstanding contributions in various fields. The selection process for the Nobel Peace Prize involves a thorough evaluation of nominations submitted by qualified individuals, while the Nobel Prize in Literature and Medicine recognizes groundbreaking research and achievements in their respective fields. Over the past 20 years, notable winners of the Nobel Prize have made significant contributions to the betterment of humanity, and their work has paved the way for new discoveries and treatments. As the Nobel Prize continues to be awarded, it serves as a testament to the power of human achievement and the importance of recognizing outstanding contributions to society.

The report should cover the purpose and goals of the Commission, its methods and findings, and any consequences arising from the report's release.
questions: What was the primary purpose of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission in South Africa?
Who headed the Truth and Reconciliation Commission in South Africa?
What was the outcome for those who confessed to atrocities during the apartheid era?

report: The Truth and Reconciliation Commission, which was established to look into the human rights violations committed during the long struggle against white rule, released its final report. In what has been described as one of the most complete reports of its kind, the commission blames most of the atrocities on the former South African government. The ANC also came under fire for committing some atrocities during the struggle. Nelson Mandella's ex-wife, Winnie could be prosecuted for the part she played in such violations. Missing from the report was De Klerk, who threatened to sue if he was mentioned in connection with the atrocities. South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission headed by Desmond Tutu proposes amnesty to heal the wounds of the apartheid era. If those accused of atrocities confess, they will be given amnesty, if not, they will be prosecuted. The Commission's report said most human rights violations were by the former state through security and law enforcement agencies. The African National Congress, Inkatha Freedom Party, and Winnie Mandela's United Football Club also shared guilt. Former president de Klerk, who shared the Nobel Peace Prize with Nelson Mandela, was not named as an accessory after the fact, since his threatened lawsuit would delay the report. South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, appointed to reconcile the sides involved in the crimes of the apartheid era, is releasing its final 2.5- year report. Its purpose is to identify those who committed gross violations of human rights. The report is to lay most of the blame for the violations on the State, but the ANC also shares blame. The program offers amnesty to the accused if they confess but execution if they refuse. The process has angered many people of all walks of life. De Klerk, Apartheid's last president, is not being implicated but he is suing to stop publication. Criminal cases are nonetheless expected to go on for six years. South Africa Truth and Reconciliation Commission's 3,500-page report on apartheid-era atrocities was issued on Oct 30. This report was intended to clear the air, grant amnesty to those who confessed, and begin the healing process. Those named for prosecution were warned before the release. Ex-prime minister de Klerk's name was removed. The ruling African National Congress remained. While the white government bore the brunt of the blame, several black movements were included. After the release many talked of a new amnesty period or a limited time to prosecute. Prosecutions could take 6 years; diverting judges, threatening elections, and slowing recovery.
response:
The Truth and Reconciliation Commission in South Africa was established to investigate and document human rights abuses committed during the apartheid era, from 1948 to 1994. The Commission's primary goal was to promote national reconciliation and provide a platform for victims to share their stories and seek justice. The Commission's chairman, Archbishop Desmond Tutu, played a crucial role in shaping the Commission's work and ensuring that it remained focused on its core objectives. Under Tutu's leadership, the Commission conducted extensive hearings and gathered evidence from over 21,000 victims and perpetrators. The Commission's final report, released in 1998, detailed findings on gross human rights violations committed by the former state, security, and law-enforcement agencies, as well as other political groupings. The report found that the South African state became involved in criminal activities, including extrajudicial killings and cover-ups, during the late 1970s to early 1990s. The Commission held certain members of the State Security Council responsible for deliberate planning that led to gross human rights violations, including the use of words that implied the killing of political opponents. Notable figures implicated in the report included former apartheid-era president F.W. de Klerk, who was found to be an accessory after the fact in the bombings of the headquarters of a church group and a labor federation in the 1980s. De Klerk's name was temporarily withheld from the report due to his objections, but it is expected to be included in the final version. The release of the report was met with mixed reactions, with some South Africans hailing it as a crucial step towards healing and reconciliation, while others criticized it for focusing too much on the past. The ANC welcomed the report, stating that it was essential for uncovering the truth and promoting reconciliation. However, the party also accused the commission of trying to "criminalize" the liberation struggle, and stated that it would always be proud of what it did to fight against the apartheid regime. The impact of the report on South Africa has been significant, with many victims and their families finding closure and justice through the Commission's work. The report has also contributed to a greater understanding of the country's complex history and the role of key figures in shaping it. Overall, the Truth and Reconciliation Commission's final report has played a crucial role in promoting national reconciliation and providing a platform for victims to share their stories and seek justice. However, the legacy of the Commission remains contentious, with ongoing debates about its value and purpose. As the country continues to grapple with the legacy of apartheid, the report remains an important tool for understanding and addressing the ongoing impacts of this period. Cited sources.

questions: Which countries adopted a common European currency, the euro, on Dec. 31, 1998?

report: Eleven countries were to adopt a common European currency, the euro, on Dec. 31, 1998. In November and December there were various reactions. France made moves toward a pan-European equity market. Ten of the countries quickly cut interest rates causing fear of overheating in some economies. In Denmark, which had earlier rejected the euro, a majority was now in favor. And in faraway China, the euro was permitted in financial exchanges. Whatever the outcome, the euro's birthday, Dec. 31, 1998, would be an historical date. Some saw it as a step towards political union while others already considered themselves as citizens of Europe. Eleven European nations are forming a "Euro zone". Britain, Denmark, Sweden, and Greece are not part of it. Danes favor joining. The Euro became official for intergovernmental transfers on Dec 31, 1998, but bills and coins will not come until 2002. The Paris, London, and Frankfurt stock exchanges have formed an alliance. Euro nations cut interest rates and inflation fell to an average 0.9%. China has authorized use of the Euro in trade. The president of the European Central Bank warns that growth is slowing and that he plans to complete his term. The EU monetary action has given rise to the new mobile, multi-lingual, non-nationalistic European. France's offer to host a financial meeting for nine other European nations is seen as a precursor to a pan-European market. It shows how the new currency, the euro, is reshaping Europe financially. Eleven European nations lowered key interest rates in preparation for the conversion. China made trading in euro official Monday when it accepted its use in trade and finance starting Jan. 1. Denmark and Sweden may not join the euro for political reasons. Some smaller nations may become unstable from a growing inflation decline. A new generation, already cosmopolitan, won't be shocked. The head of the new European Central Bank will not step down at half term. On 1 Jan 1999, the euro, a currency serving 11 European nations, entered the world financial market. As time grew short, questions remained over the pan-European market. When the head--serving an 8-year term--of the European Central Bank, which governs the euro, expressed fear of a slowing economy, the nations simultaneously dropped interest rates, spurring the market. Annual inflation rates also were encouraging. Denmark, who along with Sweden and Britain eschewed the euro, was becoming interested. As a step to a unified Europe, the euro will well serve the new, mobile, multi-lingual, business generation and could portend an economic giant.
response:
The introduction of the euro, the European common currency, marked a significant milestone in the history of the European Union. On November 1998, European nations adopting the new currency made a surprise move by dropping key interest rates. This coordinated move was a crucial step towards economic union, particularly as center-left governments in Germany and France had been pushing for lower rates to boost growth and reduce unemployment. Ten of the 11 countries adopting the euro dropped their interest rates to 3 percent, with Italy reducing its rate to 3.5 percent from 4 percent.

As the euro's launch date approached, the European nations continued to prepare for the common currency. On January 1, 1999, 11 European nations launched a common currency, and to prepare for this, they made a collective decision about monetary policy. The countries cut interest rates in a surprise move that won market confidence. Ten of the 11 countries joining the European economic union dropped their key interest rate to 3 percent, with Portugal making the most significant plunge, from 3.75 percent. Austria made the smallest cut, from 3.2 percent.

The introduction of the euro also had a significant impact on inflation rates. The annual inflation rate in the 11 nations that adopt the euro as their shared currency on Jan. 1 fell to 0.9 percent in November, the European Union's statistics agency reported. This decline continued the steady fall of inflation in the euro-zone over the past year. Annual inflation stood at 1 percent in October and 1.6 percent in November 1997, according to Eurostat's monthly report. In the 15 nation EU as a whole, inflation fell to 1 percent in November compared to 1.5 percent in the United States and 0.8 percent in Japan.

The adoption of the euro also raised concerns among some economists. With the European Central Bank setting a common interest rate for the whole bloc, some economists fear the low rate designed to boost core EU economies like France and Germany may bring overheating in smaller nations with faster growth. The latest figures may hint at trouble ahead for the euro-zone with significant increases over the year in Portugal and Ireland. European Central Bank President Wim Duisenberg made candid remarks about the economy on Friday, stating that growth appears to be slowing in the 11 countries adopting the EU common currency, the euro, on January 1. A recent area-wide survey suggested a moderation in the pace of growth, but Duisenberg remained optimistic, pointing to domestic demand as a continuing boost to the economy.

Overall, the introduction of the euro marked a significant milestone in the history of the European Union, with far-reaching implications for the economies of the participating countries. The coordinated move by European nations to drop key interest rates and the subsequent launch of the common currency set the stage for a common interest rate across the euro zone, with potential implications for economic growth and inflation rates. As the euro continues to evolve, it remains to be seen how the participating countries will navigate the challenges and opportunities presented by this new economic union. UN General Secretary Kofi Annan has met with Libyan officials and an agreement in principle has been reached on the need for a trial. Libya seeks assurances that the trial will not be politicized. Libya has been under a UN flight ban since 1992 in an effort to get them to turn over the suspected bombers for trial by Scottish authorities. The citizens of Lockerbie marked the anniversary of the bombing with a memorial service. The UN, US,and Britain continue to press Libya to turn over the two Libyans accused of the Pan Am bombing over Lockerbie, Scotland. Libya has agreed to a trial for the two by a Scottish court in the Netherlands, but if found guilty, insists they be jailed in Libya, not Scotland as Britain wants. response:
The United Nations has been actively involved in persuading Libya to extradite the two suspects in the Pan Am 103 bombing case to stand trial in Scotland. The efforts of the UN have been ongoing since 1992, when the UN Security Council imposed sanctions on Libya to force Gadhafi to surrender the two Libyans wanted in the 1988 bombing. The sanctions, which include a ban on direct flights to and from the country, have been in place for over two decades and have had a significant impact on Libya's economy.

UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan has been at the forefront of these efforts, visiting Libya on multiple occasions to meet with Gadhafi and discuss the issue. During his visits, Annan has sought to persuade Gadhafi to hand over the suspects, but Gadhafi has consistently refused, citing concerns about the suspects' rights and the possibility of them being imprisoned in Scotland. The Qatari minister has also played a role in the negotiations, presenting Gadhafi with a letter that reaffirmed Qatar's support for Libya's stance on the Lockerbie case. The letter specifically addressed Libya's objections to the UN sanctions imposed in 1992, which aimed to pressure Libya into handing over the two Libyan nationals suspected of involvement in the bombing.

The UN has proposed a compromise, under which the suspects would be tried in the Netherlands, with the possibility of serving their sentence in Dutch or Libyan prisons. However, the United States and Britain have refused to negotiate this issue, insisting that the suspects should be imprisoned in Scotland. The stalemate has continued, with the UN sanctions remaining in place and the suspects remaining in Libya. The impact of the sanctions has been significant, with Libya struggling to cope with the loss of air travel and arms sales. The sanctions have also frozen some Libyan assets abroad, further exacerbating the country's economic woes.

In conclusion, the efforts of the UN to persuade Libya to extradite the two suspects in the Pan Am 103 bombing case have been ongoing for over two decades, with little progress made. The negotiations have been complex and contentious, with multiple parties involved and competing interests at stake. Despite the challenges, the UN remains committed to resolving the issue, and the situation continues to be a major point of contention between Libya and the international community.

report: Hurricane Mitch approached Honduras on Oct. 27, 1998 with winds up to 180mph a Category 5 storm. It hit the Honduran coast on Oct. 28 bringing downpours that forced large-scale evacuations. Hun Sen and Ranariddh eventually form a coalition at summit convened by Sihanouk. Hun Sen remains prime minister, Ranariddh is president of the national assembly, and a new senate will be formed. The announcement comes after months of bitter argument following the failure of any party to attain the required quota to form a government. Opposition leader Sam Rainey was seeking assurances that he and his party members would not be arrested if they return to Cambodia. Rainey had been accused by Hun Sen of being behind an assassination attempt against him during massive street demonstrations in September. Cambodian elections, fraudulent according to opposition parties, gave the CPP of Hun Sen a scant majority but not enough to form its own government. Opposition leaders fearing arrest, or worse, fled and asked for talks outside the country. Han Sen refused. The UN found evidence of rights violations by Hun Sen prompting the US House to call for an investigation. The three-month governmental deadlock ended with Han Sen and his chief rival, Prince Norodom Ranariddh sharing power. response:
The Cambodian political crisis from 1998 to 1999 was a complex and tumultuous period marked by a struggle for power between the ruling Cambodian People's Party (CPP), led by Prime Minister Hun Sen, and the opposition FUNCINPEC party, led by Prince Norodom Ranariddh and Sam Rainsy. The crisis began after the disputed July 1998 elections, which saw massive street demonstrations organized by the opposition after Hun Sen's CPP narrowly won. The opposition alleged widespread fraud and intimidation, refusing to accept the results of the polls.

King Norodom Sihanouk played a crucial role in mediating the crisis, hosting a summit meeting to facilitate talks between the rival parties. However, Hun Sen refused to engage in international talks, accusing the opposition of trying to "internationalize" the crisis and undermine Cambodia's sovereignty. This stance led to a stalemate, with the opposition demanding that any further talks take place outside the country.

The crisis reached a boiling point in September 1998, when Sam Rainsy and his 14 members of parliament took refuge in the U.N. offices to avoid arrest after Hun Sen accused him of being behind a plot against his life. Rainsy's concerns for his safety were fueled by the tumultuous events following the election, and he eventually left Cambodia with his allies, fearing for their lives.

In a breakthrough, the rival parties reached an agreement to form a coalition government in February 1999, with Hun Sen as the sole prime minister and Ranariddh as president of the National Assembly. The agreement resolved the major political crisis and ended the deadlock that had gripped the nation since the disputed elections. The coalition government, comprising the CPP and FUNCINPEC, paved the way for international donors and businesses to resume operations in the poverty-stricken country.

Throughout the crisis, Hun Sen repeatedly called for Ranariddh and Sam Rainsy to return to Cambodia, but the opposition insisted that any further talks on the next government must take place outside the country. The ruling party guaranteed the safety and political freedom of all politicians, including Rainsy and his allies, in an effort to alleviate their fears. The deal reached between Hun Sen and Ranariddh to form a new government opened the door for Rainsy's return, but he remained cautious, citing concerns for his safety.

In conclusion, the Cambodian political crisis from 1998 to 1999 was a complex and protracted period marked by a struggle for power between the ruling CPP and the opposition FUNCINPEC party. King Sihanouk's efforts to mediate the crisis were hindered by Hun Sen's refusal to engage in international talks, leading to a stalemate and a breakdown in trust between the rival parties. Ultimately, a coalition government was formed, paving the way for international assistance and stability in the country. Cite:

The international financial crisis of 1998 had far-reaching consequences, affecting not only Russia and Ukraine but also the global economy as a whole. In Russia, the crisis led to a significant decline in the value of the ruble, causing widespread economic instability and a sharp decrease in bilateral trade with Ukraine. The Ukrainian currency, the hryvna, also suffered as a result of the crisis, leading to a withdrawal of investors and a decline in the country's economic prospects. In response to the crisis, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) provided financial assistance to both Russia and Ukraine, releasing a $2.2 billion loan to the former and offering support to the latter.

However, the IMF's actions were not without controversy. Critics argued that the fund's policies had exacerbated the problems rather than alleviating them, and that it had prioritized economic stability over poverty alleviation. The World Bank, the IMF's sister institution, was a vocal critic, accusing the IMF of neglecting the needs of the poorest countries. Even UN Secretary General Kofi Annan weighed in, warning that globalization must benefit both the rich and the poor, and that it must be harnessed to promote development and prosperity for the poorest.

The IMF's annual meeting in October 1998 was a critical test of the international community's commitment to addressing the crisis. At the meeting, the IMF discussed its funding needs, with Lagarde suggesting that the UK government's commitment of £7.2 billion may not be sufficient to meet the growing demand for assistance. The meeting also saw the EU leaders agree to boost the resources of the IMF in an effort to support economic growth and stabilize the global economy. The decision to boost IMF resources was seen as a significant step towards addressing the crisis, enabling the fund to provide more financial assistance to countries struggling to recover.

In the years following the crisis, the IMF continued to play a critical role in addressing the economic challenges faced by Russia and Ukraine. However, the fund's actions remained a subject of controversy, with many arguing that its policies had not done enough to alleviate poverty and promote development in the poorest countries. The crisis served as a reminder of the need for international cooperation and coordination in addressing global economic challenges, and the importance of prioritizing the needs of the poorest countries in any response to a crisis.

The crisis served as a reminder of the interconnectedness of the global economy and the need for international cooperation in addressing economic challenges.
